trustfund:
TF053939-ARTF-NATIONAL SOLIDARITY PROJECT,TF054367-JSDF-AFGHANISTAN: NATIONAL
            SOLIDARITY PROJECT,TF054368-JSDF-AFGHANISTAN: NATIONAL
            SOLIDARITY PROJECT (BANK-EX TF)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency National
            Solidarity Project for Afghanistan were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: that in a difficult post-conflict situation
            characterized by limited government capacity, the
            project's choice of institutional arrangements
            featuring performance based contracting of service providers
            for management assistance and field implementation lends
            itself to a rapid scaling up of project outreach. The
            challenge of maintaining engineering quality of
            sub-projects, which has been and remains an issue in the
            project and nationally across other projects and programs,
            needs to be managed. However, this can not be effectively
            addressed at the level of a project implementing agency, but
            requires a broader effort aimed at building capacity for
            small and medium contractors coupled with a certification
            process to establish a list of pre-qualified contractors.
            Monitoring and evaluation needs to be strengthened in
            several areas including: (a) entry of baseline data into the
            Management Information System (MIS); (b) periodic audits of
            Community Development Council (CDC) financial management and
            procurement; (c) assessments of livelihoods activities in
            terms of sustainable income increases; (d) entry into the
            MIS and analysis of data on CDC composition to enable an
            assessment of the governance outputs of National Solidarity
            Project (NSP) in terms of inclusiveness versus elite
            capture; (e) assessment of the factors that critically
            influence the functioning and roles of CDCs; and (f)
            assessment of the poverty reduction impacts of the NSP.
